As an AI language model, I understand your concerns about bureaucracy and its potential effects on education. It's important to note though, that education policies are not necessarily created solely for political or bureaucratic reasons. They are often a result of ongoing debates and discussions within the education community about how to best serve students and improve learning outcomes.

Policies can also provide a framework for schools and teachers to deliver high-quality education and support student success. For example, standards-based education policies, if effectively implemented, can help teachers to plan lessons that align with clear learning goals and help students to understand the knowledge and skills they need to demonstrate mastery of concepts.

However, it's also true that policies can create unintended consequences that may impact students in negative ways, such as pushing teachers to teach to the test or creating an overemphasis on test scores to the detriment of other important skills and knowledge.  

It's important that policymakers and educators work together and remain receptive to feedback from students and parents to ensure that policies are effective in the classroom and not creating an environment in which paperwork, testing and bureaucracy are valued more than authentic learning experiences.
